Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XGC-J6S1-DXH2-64VB-00000-00U.S. Bancorp at BancAnalysts Association of Boston Conference - Final2019-11-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:32ZLexisNexis110819a12826085.785U.S. Bancorp at BancAnalysts Association of Boston Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Derek Jensen White

U.S. Bancorp - Chief Digital Officer

* Terrance R. Dolan

U.S. Bancorp - Vice Chairman & CFO

Conference Call Participants

* Gerard Benson;Fidelity Investments;Equity Research Analyst

* Gerard S. Cassidy

RBC Capital Markets, Research Division - MD, Head of U.S. Bank Equity Strategy & Large Cap Bank Analyst

Presentation

GERARD S. CASSIDY, MD, HEAD OF U.S. BANK EQUITY STRATEGY & LARGE CAP BANK ANALYST, RBC CAPITAL MARKETS, RESEARCH DIVISION: We'd like to get started with the last presentation. But before we get started, I just want to thank everybody for making the 2019 BancAnalysts Association of Boston Conference a real success. Well, The Langham Hotel, which is under reconstruction, which is why we're here at the Four Seasons will not be finished next year, so you could expect to come back here next year.

But just really, with the Board and myself, I want to thank everybody for coming, and I'll turn it over to Gerry Benson.

GERARD BENSON;FIDELITY INVESTMENTS;EQUITY RESEARCH ANALYST: All right. Thank you, Gerard. So up next, the last presentation of the day, we have U.S. Bancorp. U.S. Bancorp is the nation's fifth-largest commercial bank, headquartered in Minneapolis, Minnesota with $488 billion in assets. They provide a comprehensive line of banking, mortgage, investment, trust and payment services products to consumers, businesses and institutions. They consistently rank in the top quartile in performance metrics relative to peers.

Presenting today for U.S. Bancorp, we have Terry Dolan, Chief Financial Officer. Terry joined U.S. Bancorp in 1998 and was named CFO in 2016. And joining Terry is Derek White, Chief Digital Officer. So please join me in welcoming.

DEREK JENSEN WHITE, CHIEF DIGITAL OFFICER, U.S. BANCORP: Thank you, Gerry. It's great to be with all of you today. I was encouraged to give just a little bit of background on myself before I get started.

But actually, before I begin, I'd like to remind you that any forward-looking statements made today are subject to risk and uncertainty. Please review Slide 2 for more information.

Just to give you a bit more color on my own background, I've been out of the United States for the last 14 years. But before that, I was an entrepreneur in college, started a business that was a sports and marketing business. One of my clients was a financial institution called First USA Bank back in the day. Upon graduation from college, this client of mine, First USA, asked me to join them. We then built up a sports entertainment marketing business within First USA Bank. While at First USA Bank, I also participated in the creation of Wingspan, one of the first real Internet banks as well as their international business under the brand of Bank One.

Following that, left First USA Bank, raised $20 million from Bill Gurley to create what was Juniper Bank, a start-up de novo Internet bank, starting in '99 and 2000. We built that business and after 5 years exited that business to Barclays. It is now Barclays' cards and deposit business here in the United States.

As part of that sale to Barclays was asked to move across the pond. What was supposed to be 6 months turned into 14 years. We spent 2 years outside of London, 4 years in Dubai, 5 years back in London and then that stint at Barclays, which included work in emerging markets, in Dubai, and worked across all the business lines, my role in Barclays ended as Chief Design and Digital Officer across the enterprise, working with all business lines to create the future. And then went to BBVA, the European leader in efficiency and in digital, and led what was called Client Solutions at BBVA.

I joined U.S. Bank just about 5 months ago now in the role of Chief Digital Officer. Within this role, we look at -- some core teams within the role are an omnichannel team that looks across all interfaces of our human customers interacting with their money. I'll come on to that in a little bit more. Agile, that looks at how we create the future of the bank in a different way as well as the new innovation team that's looking at where are we going next and ask the questions as to why not. We also are looking very closely at emerging payments in RTP and other areas of the business, working with all of my peers on how we connect humans and money and how we monetize that through the financial products we offer through our businesses today.

Just moving to the slide deck and a couple of slides for today. Interactions, I believe, are the leading indicator for the future of every industry. And in banking, we have the privilege of working with every industry. We sit with the titans of industry and look at the future of their businesses. And the one thing that we see is how humans are interacting increasingly in digital and how that's changing from analog or traditional businesses into digital businesses. Interactions are a leading indicator for every industry. And how that translates into those interactions and how humans interact with a product and in banking, how they interact with money and how we, therefore, monetize those interactions is changing.

You can see on the top left that in U.S. Bank today, 70% of our customers are already digital. They've already gone there. Our customers are choosing to interact with their money in digital. On the right-hand side, you can see this visually represented by the customer interactions over a 48-hour period, 48-hour window, a glimpse into how our customers interact with their money. The blue line that you see there is humans, customers walking into our branches, interacting with their money and with our employees in our branches. The orange highlights our customer interactions on the consumer side of our business interacting with their money in digital.

Now there are 2 key things of why we show this. One, to show that even at the peak hours our branches are open and digital is open at about 3x as long as the physical door. Our customers are choosing to interact with their money or their company's money through digital at a multiple beyond that of which they do in physical. The second is to highlight that the digital door is always open, whereas the physical door, whether it's an office or whether it's a branch, closes. And digital allows our customers to interact with their money when and how they want. Now the important point is that as we move from a traditional bank to a digital bank and increasingly to a digital company is recognizing that as human behavior changes and human interactions change with money, therefore, the way that we monetize those interactions is quite different.

On the next slide, we outline how we're translating the vision that I shared at Investor Day, how we're translating that into our 6 key priorities at this stage of our digital evolution within U.S. Bank. The first of those is DIY for all 4 humans. The concept of DIY again applies across every industry. The simple ability for a human to be able to interact with a product and their money by themselves on a mobile device without requiring any other human intervention or help.

We define the 4 humans of banking as the consumer that makes decisions about my money. The small business that makes decisions about my money and my company's money and how they mix those together very frequently. The third human is the corporate executive, whether it's a family office, whether it's a corporate banker or sorry, a treasurer or a CFO and they're making decisions about their employer's money. The last is the U.S. Bank employee that is at the service of the other 4 humans.

This is important because in the digital world, we design around the human experience, human journey and I'm going to bring that to life even more. We design around those 4 humans and how those 4 humans interface with money, increasingly through digital, how you build and design a digital experience and then how you monetize it through those financial products that exist in that digital layer, that digital interface. It's all incredibly important. The first phase of any analog brick business moving to digital is the DIY and open the digital door. So the digital door is open to every feature, journey, experience that exists through a physical door.

Sorry. Before I get into a click-through or a double-click on each of these 6 priorities, I'd like to touch on this concept that we find very powerful in bringing our colleagues in the organization and how we organize our work around what we call above the glass and below the glass.

As we look at the 4 humans that exist above the glass, and again, touching on DIY for them, it's about building DIY-able experiences so they can do everything by themselves if they want to, if they want to, which we see they do. And the second is creating smart and personalized interactions and increasingly, at some point, autonomous interactions that actually use the data that we have captured within the organization and bring that back through the glass at the interaction level with our customers.

Now you can think of this simply, above the glass what matters in digital banking is billions and basis points. Now as bankers we're really good at managing billions and we're good at measuring against basis points. Why billions matter and what matters in the artificial intelligence, the machine learning world, Ray Kurzweil, one of the greatest inventors of our time has said that AI, artificial intelligence, becomes real or becomes alive when you talk about billions. And we have billions of interactions with our customers today.

And looking at one of the hottest jobs in the digital world today is this concept called funnel management, as illustrated on the slide here. The way e-commerce companies manage sales and manage clicks and experiences in their world. Because simple tweaks to understanding how humans are interacting in a digital world, of how the billions of interactions at the top of the funnel translate into sales, into better, more efficient experiences at the bottom of the funnel and tweaks along every step of the way, whether it's clicks, whether it's taps, whether it's screens, whether it's prefilled or manually entered, are basic elements of digital.

And that's where we look at, is the digital door open? And then how do we make sure the experience and the billions of interactions that we have are amazing experiences. And small tweaks along the way, the science and the art brought together in tweaks, translates into greater bottom line impact in both sales that drives positive revenue as well as efficiency that creates positive jaws for us across the board. I could give you examples of this, of what we see as kind of best-in-class. The companies that we benchmark ourselves against are like the Booking.coms of the world as to how simple the experience is in travel.

You look at the traditional supermarkets and how easy is it to buy toothpaste online versus the way Amazon does it today. Is it 12 clicks or is it 1? All of that translates into funnel management from top to the bottom. I risk boring you with the science of this so let me move on to how the above the glass translates into the work that is done actually below the glass.

The below the glass things, we have 2 of our key priorities below the glass are around building a human-centric database -- I'm going to come on to that in a minute -- rather than product-centric, called Human 360 and reusable technologies. Driving those are data, the infrastructure and the human capital that we bring into the organization to ensure that we create a clean, reusable, reliable architecture below the glass that will drive efficiency, that will drive enormous customer satisfaction.

So let's, if we can, step through each of these 6 priorities or double-click on them to give you a bit more color around each of them. I mentioned that our goal is to DIY everything possible for the 4 humans. Now this is very measurable. And as bankers, we like to measure things. And so this is very measurable. And just to bring this to life, human #1, the consumer, each of us interacting with our money. You want to do 440 things with your money potentially. That is the perimeter. That is the potential of things that you might want to do with your money. Knowing that 440 is important. Why? Because we can dimension what it is that people, humans, want to do with money. Knowing those 440 things, we can then measure, are they available or are they not?

The top banks today are somewhere around 75-plus percent DIY-able in the consumer space. Consumer is more digitally advanced on DIY than the institutional businesses. If you say that in consumer businesses, say, 75-plus percent DIY-able as to why I would take my time and walk into a branch, it's 75%. On the institutional side, it may be 25% to 30%, showing and demonstrating enormous opportunity to simply start at the very basic level of digitizing a business, creating a digital business by looking at DIY, what are the journeys, what are the features, what are the things that CFOs, treasurers want to be able to do, and can they do it DIY? All of this, again, translates into positive revenues, efficiencies and greater customer experience.

By focusing on DIY and understanding what humans want to do with their money and how they interact with their money and the products that we monetize them through, we can then look at innovations that pop out of looking at each of these individual experiences, each of these individual journeys. And by prioritizing what matters most to the customer in a very simple level, 2 things. What matters most to the customer and how do we make money. Bringing those together, there's 2 examples that we've highlighted here that we have found resonate with our customers.

One example is Expense Wizard. So for any small business, for example, that wants to be able to -- or that their employees are managing their travel expenses, no one likes to keep track of the receipts and the paper receipts. Simply digitizing that experience that wouldn't necessarily be a traditional financial product but adds value to our customers, by creating that, it eliminates -- we give a virtual card, a corporate card to those customers. It creates a greater experience. It removes wastage out of the system. It reduces accounting risk. And it also gives a line of sight into forward purchasing power, which, from a data perspective, is incredibly powerful. And because you're shifting transactions from consumer card interchange to corporate card interchange, there's a very positive monetization opportunity.

The third is looking at geolocation within our mobile application. The ability for customers to be able to tie where they're actually purchasing with their mobile application, geolocation, has great benefits and helps us manage fraud, helps us help our customers, reduces call volume, problems with our customers, declined transactions and is driving great adoption across the board for our customers.

The second priority is this concept of once we make everything digitally available, then are we making it smart? Are we making it intelligent? Of the 440 things, are we using the data that we have today and bringing it back through the glass to the customer, to me, the end user, so that when I'm interacting in this platform, is my data helping me make decisions in a better way? You can see in banking, we've done a great job of capturing data, cleaning data, and then there's a lot of concept about putting it into a data lake, but that isn't the magic. The magic is pulling the data out of the lake, unlocking the lake. Yes, you want it to be safe and secure and be able to access it, but pulling it out of the lake back through the glass to the end user is where the magic happens. And this is where there's enormous opportunity in the future of banking at a per interaction level looking at, is the data used in the billions of interactions that we have with our customers and measuring how smart are our interaction.

Two examples of that, that we have within the company today that are these pockets of brilliance that we have within U.S. Bank. One of them is this -- we've served up since April in our new mobile banking application. We served up 400 million insights to our customers, where we help them understand their money better. And 85% of those insights, our customers come back and tell us that it's valuable, educational and driving greater interactions for them. On the second side is in our institutional business and the Corporate Trust business. You may or may not be aware of Pivot. But in the digital world, we call this a killer app. Anything that has over 50% market share in customer adoption resonates in what is called product market fit.

And in our Corporate Trust business, our customers today, our clients today are using Pivot to translate complex trade scenario analysis into visual decision-making tool that used to take 60 to 90 minutes now takes 1 to 2. Using data and presenting data in a way that is actionable and tangible for the end user, also giving projected and real-time cash flow at a moment's notice, that is, we find, incredibly valuable for our clients. Taking the learnings from Pivot and then bringing it into our other platforms across our other institutional businesses based on the product market fit, the design and how it resonates with the end user is an opportunity for us as we move forward.

The third priority that we've outlined, and I'll try to keep up with the slides here. The third priority that we've outlined is, if the what we want to do above the glass is DIY and smart, then how we do it, moving at speed and at scale is our third priority. And looking at the thousands of employees we now have across the organization across our Agile Studios, creating the way fintechs do, creating the way big tech does, bringing together financial products, the experience and technology all together in working scrums and teams in the agile way of working has enormous benefits.

It increases our speed to market in a positive way. We're able to validate our product market fit increasingly. Our time to revenue improves. But perhaps the most powerful of this and from a cultural standpoint when you talk about transforming the culture of an organization is that we get better at predicting the work that we need to do. By measuring on a fortnightly basis, on a quarterly basis the work that we think we want to get done, measuring that and being able to say, did we get 55% of what we said we were going to get done or did we get 85% of what we wanted to get done is incredibly powerful for colleagues to see that. And to see that we are good at predicting how we work and how we're going to deliver and increasing the speed at which we deliver.

Priority #4 is about building a human-centric database below the glass, connecting our data ecosystem and the data that we have that I already touched on in our data lake, making sure that it is easily accessible for us to be able to pull back through the glass is incredibly important. And measuring the usage of the data in the right ethical way, the way U.S. Bank has a reputation of trust and ethics is what we're focused on. And this will all be, we will be looking to integrate external data through APIs, using our internal data. All of this will be optimizing our core data infrastructure and also making sure that we bring in the right human capital that looks at it in the way that humans are interacting in digital.

Now this one might be a little bit too technical for the crowd, but this is where speed and efficiency become incredibly tangible and real. See, banking was built on financial products. And each financial product, if you want to take an analog financial product and you want to make it digital, the first step that many have done is to simply create a web application form or a web form. On the left-hand side, that's what this illustrates, is being able to take one product and make it digital, you would create from top to bottom, above the glass to below the glass, a siloed structure. And if you have 5 products, you would build all of the same components all the way across all 5 products.

Now on the right-hand side, by using this technology, and again, not to bore you, but the concept of microservices and APIs allows us to look across. And why Andy created this role is that he saw the opportunity for us to look across all of our financial products, see that they're becoming digital. These financial products come together in one digital interface. They're calling on services below the glass. And there's an opportunity for us to create once and reuse, which is the overall concept of an API. Instead of having multiple point-to-point solutions, creating services that if you have the 440 things above the glass and translating that into 900 microservices below the glass that can be reusable, that translates into efficiency.

Now the last item is how we look at the monetization of this, these human interactions in these interfaces across the company. And if we look at each of the financial products that exist today across the company, each of them will be made digital. And each of them will have a unique profit model in how we manifest them and how we generate revenues and efficiencies in a profit model per product at a digital level as well as through the traditional level. And there are ways that we can measure and monetize that.

And this is incredibly powerful and incredibly exciting. If you look at our organization less as an organizational chart and more like an operating system or the way network science works in the digital way. And that each of these P&L centers across the bank are points on an operating network and they're origins of where the P&L comes from, how we manifest that and bring that together in digital is incredibly exciting.

With that, I'll bring my comments to a close and I'll hand it over to Terry.

TERRANCE R. DOLAN, VICE CHAIRMAN & CFO, U.S. BANCORP: Thanks, Derek. Derek's been in the organization for about 6 months. I think you joined in April. And here's one of the things that I really appreciate about his leadership within our organization. I think of people in terms of 2 different groups, those that take the simple and make them complex and those that take the complex and make it simple. And Derek fits into that second category. He's really in a relatively short period of time been able to take what I would call, areas of excellence within our organization from a digital standpoint, think about our mortgage products that we talked about, our small business products that we talked about and our Pivot, as an example, in those areas of excellence, and he's been able to really look across the entire organization and help us really provide clarity with respect to what we need to be able to achieve from a digital standpoint.

One of our strategies is what we call One U.S. Bank. And what One U.S. Bank is all about is really being able to take the things that we do well within our product areas, our silos, if you will, our lines of businesses and really to think across the entire organization to be able to leverage everything we do in a way that it logically makes a lot more sense from a customer standpoint. So I appreciate that about his joining our team.

Everything he talked about and everything that we focus on within U.S. Bank is about creating value, creating value to our customers and our shareholders. And that's what this is all about.

I think about it in terms of 3 things. And Derek has talked about each one of these things. How do you end up thinking about digital and the services and products that you offer, that you're going to offer to your customers and how do you end up monetizing it in order to be able to get the economics out of it. That's the revenue side of the equation. The other side of the equation is, how do you end up thinking about the cost structure of the organization going into the future. How do you end up optimizing it in order to be able to get the value, the cost efficiencies out of the organization that you should get? And all of that with both a long-term and a short-term perspective in terms of how you end up managing the business because you have to be able to create sustainable cost structures that enable you to continuously reinvest in the business. And that is clearly a very significant goal for us at U.S. Bank.

One of the things, just as an example, we've talked about at Investor Day was our physical asset optimization. This is clearly an example where our customers' behaviors are changing in the branches. They're adopting digital in a very rapid pace. Today, 70% to 80% of service related to transactions that used to occur in the branches are happening above the glass and below the glass within the digital space. And so we're in the process of optimizing our physical asset structure in order to recognize that change in behavior. And we talked about the fact that we plan to close 10% to 15% of the branches over the course of the next year or so. And I also believe that there's opportunity to be able to expand upon that as we think about the future.

It's not just closing branches though, it's also opening branches. It's remodeling branches. It's moving branches, relocating branches into the right areas of our communities in order to be able to capture the highest level of growth. And it's also, from an employee perspective, rethinking the roles within the organization. What are the roles, what are the skill sets that are no longer needed or need to be de-emphasized in the organization and which ones do we need to expand upon and grow in the organization. And how do we allow and enable our employees to be able to make that transition.

In addition to the closure of the branches in our existing footprint, we're also looking at opening branches in new markets. These are markets where it will be a branch-lite, digital-first sort of strategy. We recently opened our first branch in Charlotte. We will have a network, we believe, of somewhere between 8 and 10 branches in that particular market and a network of ATMs of about 150 ATMs in order to be able to create a sense of presence within that community. And then using the digital tools that we have at our disposal and that we will roll out. We believe that, that is a strategy that can be very successful.

We are targeting markets where we already have presence, either from an employee perspective or a significant customer presence, either through our card business, our mortgage business, our auto business or a combination of all 3 of those. So these are customers that we already know and we want to be able to do business with and being able to use that branch-lite, digital-first strategy is how we're thinking about success in this particular area, at least in the near term.

So just to kind of wrap this up and then we'll take it to questions. U.S. Bank, as you know, is a company that is in a position of strength. We have the opportunity to be able to take that position of strength and the competitive advantages that we have as a result of that in order to be able to invest in our business. I think there are companies that are either going to be able to make that investment and embrace the digital transformation or not. And we want to be an organization that is embracing the digital change. And bringing Derek on as the Chief Digital Officer is going to enable us to be able to get there.

And with that, I'll close and we'll go to questions, I guess, Gerry. Thank you.

Questions and Answers

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Derek, I'd like to ask you about the long-term trend given you've had a very unique view of international, really high competition, future stuff. What opportunities and threats do you see with banks over the next 10 to 20 years, how the industry is going to change? And actually, given that you've worked at BBVA, a well-respected bank that's based in Europe, can you also include how open banking is going to change the banking sector there?

DEREK JENSEN WHITE: Sure. Sorry, do we repeat the question or go ahead?

GERARD BENSON;FIDELITY INVESTMENTS;EQUITY RESEARCH ANALYST: Yes. If you want to paraphrase.

DEREK JENSEN WHITE: Okay. The question is in regard to trends, 10 to 20 years out even as well as views on open banking.

Trends, 10 to 20 years out, there are 20,000 banks in the world today, depending on how you measure it, somewhere between 16,000 to 20,000 banks in the world today, 6,000 to 7,000 of those banks exist here in the United States.

The indications, there are still markets around the world where 40 to 50-plus percent of the local country's population still do not have bank accounts. That is, as they describe in the emerging markets, world bankerizing at a rapid pace, but we're also seeing developments of monetary systems that sit outside of the traditional banking world. That is one opportunity. It is also a threat. Therefore, one of the key drivers of that will be the -- and as you look around the different regions of the world, from China, to Europe, to the United States is 3 kind of regions, the role of regulation is perhaps the greatest delineator of what banks do versus what big tech does versus what fintech does.

If you take China versus the United States, there's clear delineation in the United States as to what large ecosystems, large tech players, what large retailers can do in the banking space. That does not exist in the same way in China.

In Europe, which leads to the discussion on -- and we could talk much more about larger trends 10 to 20 years out, but there will be consolidation from the 20,000, call it, 20,000 banks down to, is it dozens in the future operating at a global scale or at a local market scale? There will be large consolidation. Technology will be a driver of that, both above and below the glass. Human adoption of that technology and how human behavior is comfortable engaging and making decisions around technology interaction with money will be a massive driver. Because at present, humans are interacting with technology in other spheres. That human behavioral adoption hasn't fully migrated to banking. And then regulation, those would be the big themes I would suggest long term.

As far as open banking, Europe is quite advanced in open banking. Who would have thought that GDPR-PSD2 could serve as -- that regulation could serve as a catalyst for innovation. It's happening in Europe. And as you see, the portability of data, the portability and the ability for a third party to initiate a payment on behalf of a customer and increasingly placing the ability for end users, customers to have more influence over their data is very clearly a trend that we will all be looking at. We, within U.S. Bank, do have an open banking platform. We are externalizing APIs in the right way. And there are different types of APIs, from data, to financial product, that can be exposed through open banking. The U.S. has some room for development in open banking.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: How far along are you in the Human 360? I mean how much of your data is kind of reusable? And do you have the infrastructure to fully implement a reusable tech aspect?

DEREK JENSEN WHITE: The question is, how far are we along on priorities 4 and 5 that I've outlined on Human 360 and reusable tech.

I'd describe that as, we have one common core banking system across the bank, across all of the enterprise. We have a fairly clean architecture below the bank or sorry, below the glass that allows us to capture data, clean the data, store the data in a way that is reusable or is accessible for us to use. And the technology enables that. But we're on a journey. We have some work to do. But the path, most importantly, the path is very clear as to where we're heading. I'd hesitate to put an exact point on where we are in the journey, but we have a very clear path as to where we're heading. We have a clean environment and we're moving.

One of the great things, again, coming from outside of U.S. Bank inside U.S. Bank is [between] the platforms that we have, but most importantly, the simple business model. Our size allows us to move and will enable us to move at speed in the future.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Derek, your experience at WingspanBank, which reminds me of the time when we had this massive innovation where there was the existential threat from the original kind of de novo opportunities and you kind of alluded to it. But I guess what's different now versus then? Is it just the speed? Is it the technology? And why won't the banking system be able to defend against it like it did when there was kind of flash in the pan things that kind of came and ended up not being quite the disintermediators that they were going to be?

DEREK JENSEN WHITE: So the question is, the likes of Wingspan came about had a big splash and appeared to be a big threat, what's changed? And I think that's...

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Can the system defend against...

DEREK JENSEN WHITE: Can the system defend?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: (inaudible) the thing is for real and really different than other prior disintermediation, new technologies. Do you think you can defend better today than you did with dot com?

DEREK JENSEN WHITE: Yes. The Internet was not designed to move money. The Internet was designed as a messaging platform and informational platform, but not designed for what it is today, and there's a lot of discussion on the evolution of the web. But the early advent of the Wingspans of the world, of making things available digitally on digital was the first phase. The second phase came about when mobile happened. And mobile happened and that changed the way that customers can take portability outside of the office and can DIY essentially anywhere that they want.

Again, I would suggest, while there's the human behavioral aspect of this and where humans already are, one of the biggest defenses is regulation that will protect what can and cannot be done. Because there are markets outside of the United States, for example, in Kenya, where 40-plus percent of the GDP moves through a currency that is mobile minutes, that is not a sovereign currency. That doesn't happen in every market. And regulation plays a role in the monetary system as well as defining the currency that moves through that monetary system.

I think we're in a position where fintechs have dissected banking into narrow experiences. But as those fintechs mature, what you see is the customers, the humans demanding a greater expanse in product offering beyond just their narrow offerings. So they're getting these multi-unicorn, decacorn valuations but monetizing through one financial product today and customers will start to demand more financial products as we mature.

TERRANCE R. DOLAN: I think the other thing, we talk about it from a strategic perspective at the Board, even over the course of the last 5 years, 10, 15 years ago, you might have had some of the fintech sort of activities or the Internet banking. But the advent of the significant investment in fintech on one side, of the huge tech companies on the other side that really are looking at how do you end up being relevant to the customer and it's all about the interactions and then how do you end up monetizing those interactions. And that is significantly different today than it was back then, which I think creates a huge threat.

DEREK JENSEN WHITE: One of the big things that we see with the big techs, and we have relationships with all of them. Big tech has 3 priorities: scale to billions of users, increase the amount of interactions and time that their users are spending on their platform, then monetize through ads or through services or through products. We have a goal of having millions of customers, billions of interactions and monetizing through financial products. We meet at the interaction level, right?

And one of the key things as we look to that is that each of the big techs, many of the big techs, they're experimenting in how payments bridges into their ecosystem because that is the natural bridge where the financial ecosystem meets the tech ecosystem, it starts with payments. And a lot of the big techs have experimented on how payments increase with the amount of time and the number of interactions, which is their priority #2. One of their priorities is not to generate revenue through financial products, but the increased time, interactions on their platforms that they monetize through their traditional tech. And understanding that and how we can then partner with them, work with them and where they may be a threat is really important.

TERRANCE R. DOLAN: The other thing that I would add is just, if you think about -- one of the things that we have been trying to articulate is the importance of the payments business for U.S. Bank and I think our success as we think about that in the future. And I think, Derek, it's kind of worth spending just a minute or 2 on your thoughts regarding that.

DEREK JENSEN WHITE: Yes. So one of the greatest things that we have within U.S. Bank is the 2 sides of the payments marketplace. And I think many people underestimate the value of having that. Having worked in Turkey, which outside of China is arguably the most advanced payments market in the world and a business there that has both sides of the marketplace, there are very few of our peers in the United States that have the acquiring and the issuing side of the marketplace. There are enormous benefits from having both of those. Because one, understanding a payments ecosystem and understanding the movement of money in that ecosystem and having 2 sides of the marketplace is incredibly valuable. Not only having that from an ecosystem standpoint, but Andy and Terry and Shailesh have spoken about the benefits of having payments and banking together.

Because see, as we have payments and understanding that tech's entry and threat into banking is starting primarily through payments because payments means data as well. Payments also allows us on both sides of the marketplace to bridge into banking. On the consumer side, on the issuing side is swipes, and they're using their card, we can then offer them banking products through the interactions that we have with them. On the merchant acquiring side, that allows us to then build deeper relationships on the institutional side of the house. So those 2 dimensions of understanding the 2 sides of the marketplace, and if we had more time, we could really bring to life the power of that and the bridging of that, but then also the banking side of it is incredibly powerful. And I think many analysts and others underestimate the power of having both sides of that marketplace.

GERARD BENSON;FIDELITY INVESTMENTS;EQUITY RESEARCH ANALYST: Thanks, Derek. Actually, that's all the time we have now. We have a buffet lunch next door. But please, let's thank Derek, Terry and [Jen].

Corporate Participants

* Andrew Cecere

U.S. Bancorp - Chairman, President & CEO

* Derek Jensen White

U.S. Bancorp - Chief Digital Officer

* Gunjan Kedia

U.S. Bancorp - Vice Chairman of Wealth Management & Investment Services

* James B. Kelligrew

U.S. Bancorp - Vice Chairman of Corporate & Commercial Banking

* Jeffry H. von Gillern

U.S. Bancorp - Vice Chairman of Technology & Operations Services

* Jodi L. Richard

U.S. Bancorp - Vice Chairman & Chief Risk Officer

* Katherine B. Quinn

U.S. Bancorp - Vice Chairman & Chief Administrative Officer

* Leslie J. V. Godridge

U.S. Bancorp - Vice Chairman of Corporate & Commercial Banking

* Mark G. Runkel

U.S. Bancorp - Executive VP & Chief Credit Officer

* Shailesh M. Kotwal

U.S. Bancorp - Vice Chairman of Payment Services

* Terrance R. Dolan

U.S. Bancorp - Vice Chairman & CFO

* Timothy A. Welsh

U.S. Bancorp - Vice Chairman of Consumer Banking Sales & Support

Conference Call Participants

* Betsy Lynn Graseck

Morgan Stanley, Research Division - MD

* Christoph M. Kotowski

Oppenheimer & Co. Inc., Research Division - MD and Senior Analyst

* Erika Najarian

BofAMerrill Lynch, Research Division - MD and Head of US Banks Equity Research

* Gerard S. Cassidy

RBC Capital Markets, LLC, Research Division - Analyst

* John Eamon McDonald

Autonomous Research LLP - Senior Analyst Large-cap Banks

* John G. Pancari

Evercore ISI Institutional Equities, Research Division - Senior MD & Senior Equity Research Analyst

* Kenneth Michael Usdin

Jefferies LLC, Research Division - MD and Senior Equity Research Analyst

* Matthew D. O'Connor

Deutsche Bank AG, Research Division - MD in Equity Research

* Michael Lawrence Mayo

Wells Fargo Securities, LLC, Research Division - Senior Analyst

* Robert Scott Siefers

Sandler O'Neill + Partners, L.P., Research Division - Principal of Equity Research

* Saul Martinez

UBS Investment Bank, Research Division - MD & Analyst

* Vivek Juneja

JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division - Senior Equity Analyst

Presentation

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to U.S. Bancorp's 2019 Investor Day. Thank you to all of you who have joined us here in New York, who are listening on our webcast. We have a full agenda for you today, including a Q&A session at the end of the day where we're going to bring all of our presenters back on stage and you'll have an opportunity to ask any questions you might have.

During the day, you'll also have an opportunity at breaks and at lunch to go and visit our tech experience displays outside in the foyer. We have a number of our technology products that you can take a look at and take -- also talk to some of our tech ambassadors out there. All of our presentations today are available on our website at usbank.com.

Aside from all of the presenters you're going to be seeing here on stage today, we have with us in attendance our entire managing committee as well as over 25 of our most senior leaders here at the bank. They're here seated amongst you in the ballroom. They're also, as I mentioned, outside acting as tech ambassadors and with our tech displays. We encourage you all to seek them out during the day, talk to them. They're here to answer your questions. Not only to give you a better understanding of our businesses and our opportunities for growth, but also to give you a better sense of our culture and who we are as a company. We're also thrilled that 9 members of our Board of Directors were able to join us here today. And I want to take a moment and ask our Board members to just please stand and be recognized.

With us are David O'Maley, Art Collins, Olivia Kirtley, Dorothy Bridges. Over here, we have Elizabeth Buse, Kimberly Harris, David McKenney, Dr. O'dell Owens, and we are going to be having Doreen Woo Ho later join us.

Before we get started, I need to remind you that today's presentations are going to be including forward-looking statements that may be subject to risk and uncertainty. The factors that may cause those actual results to differ from those statements are included in the presentations on our website today as well as in our 10-K and future SEC filings. Some of our presentations are also going to include reference to non-GAAP financial measures. A list of those -- of -- I'm sorry, a description of those non-GAAP financial measures as well as reconciliations to GAAP are also included in our presentation as well as our SEC filings. With that, let's get started.

(presentation)

ANDREW CECERE, CHAIRMAN, PRESIDENT & CEO, U.S. BANCORP: Good morning. A lot certainly has changed. My favorite part of that presentation was the 2 to 10 year, did you see that? That was the only thing that was consistent, right? Heading downward.

I'm Andy Cecere, CEO of U.S. Bank. It's my pleasure to welcome you to the 2019 Investor Day.

First of all, let me thank you. I know you have a lot of pressures on your time, and I recognize that it's your choice to come here this morning, and I want to thank you for that.

I want to thank you for taking the time to listen to our story, and I want to thank you for the investment in our company. I believe we have a great story to tell. I believe we're positioned in an excellent place to win in this new environment, and I want to talk a little bit about what's changed over the last 3 years.

If you think about the evolving world we're in, let me start with the economic scenario. And I'll start by telling you that we have a lot of data at the company. A lot of early indicators that we look at in the credit group, in the payments group and so forth and none of those indications are recession upcoming. You're going to hear from Jodi and Mark a little later that our credit staff, as it relates to the consumer, commercial and corporate banking groups, are all consistent and stable.

From a spend standpoint, we have a lot of data there also. And as you recall at the end of 2018, there's little bit of a dip in spend activity, particularly on the consumer side of the equation. And as we talked about on the last 2 earnings call, this started to continue to go up, and we're seeing that stability there also, so spend is stable.

And finally, if you think about loan demand, that's also very consistent. You'll hear from Terry later, but that consistency has been in place for the last couple of quarters. So our data would indicate stable, continuing growing economy.

Now at the same time as you all know, we have conflicting messages as you think about global growth, China, trade, tariffs and Brexit. And probably most of all, what you're seeing in the yield curve and the indications about something might be happening. And that, sort of, conflicting set of messages is creating a lot of volatility, uncertainty in the marketplace absolutely, and we have to be able to react to that on an ongoing basis.

From a changing expectation standpoint, quite a lot has changed. But the one I want to focus on is individuals and businesses expectations around privacy and trust in technology. That is a fairly recent change in just the last almost 12 months that people have a heightened awareness of how their data's being used, and their protection of privacy of that data is becoming even more important to them.

From a regulatory environment, we've come a long way. You can think about the last 10 years, there was a tremendous increase in regulatory oversight in the banking industry, increased capital levels, increased liquidity levels. And I will say overall the banking industry is in a much safer, better place today. Now the last 3 years I would call more moderate and stable, and there's a lot of clarity and there was -- there hasn't been actually increases in regulatory oversight in the industry overall.

And in fact, I would say, a lot of the focus has shifted from capital and liquidity to overall reputation and operational risk and that's an area of focus that you'll hear a little bit about more in a moment.

And then finally, probably the most significant change that's occurred is related to technology and the digital revolution.

The fact is our customers, U.S. Bank customers, banking customers are all -- overall are impacted not just about what's happening in the banking industry but what's happening in the industries across the United States, and the expectations and the way they're dealing with the bank has changed quite dramatically.

If you think about 10 years ago, just about every transaction that occurred in the bank, occurred in the 4 walls of a branch. And today, 2/3 of transactions occur on a digital device, that's quite a change over a 10-year time frame. And even over the last couple of years that's moved up from about 50% to 67% and it continues -- that curve continues to be very steep. And customers' expectations around convenience and speed, uncertainty and safety and privacy have also increased quite dramatically. So that means for us that we have to rethink about the role of the branch, the number of branches and how we think about our branch network, and you're going to hear a lot more about that today. And certainly, the competitive landscape has changed.

You met a number of our Board of Directors, we have an annual strategic off-site that we talk to our Board every year. We've been doing that for the past 10 years and we talk about our competitors. And for many of those 10 years, our competitors would have been those circles around the blue U.S. Bank, principally our peer group banks. But as the Board knows, the last 3 years, we've expanded that quite dramatically to include the large tech platforms on the left and the fintech players on the right. Because the fact is, those are our competitors today just as much as the other banks. They are entering the financial services area -- arena principally through payments and money movement.

Banking traditionally, particularly deposit taking and lending, has a pretty wide moat around it. It's a regulated business and many of the fintech players and large tech platforms are not in that. However, they're entering through payments and sometimes creating partnerships to expand beyond that. And we recognize that and this is one of the key themes that you're going to hear today is that combination of payments and banking, I think, is as critical as it's ever been in the last few years. So a lot has changed in the environment. A lot has changed in the industry and a lot has changed at U.S. Bank. If you think about the last 3 years, we've done over 17 acquisitions, card portfolios, trust portfolios and a lot of increased capabilities, one of which we announced earlier this week. Software capabilities or payments capabilities across the board. We announced our first expansion into a new market in 10 years. Next month, we're going to go into Charlotte, North Carolina with what we're calling a digital first branch-light strategy, and Tim is going to talk a lot more about our thinking around that.

Kate will talk about brand campaign, but I will tell you that our name recognition, our brand awareness is much stronger today than it was just 3 years ago and certainly 6 years ago. We've gone from a regional bank to a national bank and that brand awareness is certainly out there. And finally, we've had a number of enhancements and product introductions across every customer segment in the bank and every single business line.

From a flexibility standpoint, probably one of the most significant changes is exiting the consent order. We were in the AML consent order for 3 years. And while we were in that order, we were increasing our expense base both from a technology and operational standpoint as well as the number of people focused on that initiative. The good news is we're past that heightened spend. We're in the stability phase as we sit today. And in fact, you're going to hear from Jodi, our objective is to optimize our overall risk management function.

The second important component of that is while we were in that consent order, we were bound and could not open new branches, which really limited our flexibility in terms of closing branches because we wanted to optimize the locations. And as a result of exiting that we, as you know, announced a 10% to 15% reduction in branches and a very different phase of the branches that branch that remains. What goes on in those 4 walls, as I talked about and Tim will talk about more, is very different today than it was just a few years ago. And that flexibility allows efficiency and effectiveness. And speaking of efficiency and effectiveness, if you look at the tech side of the equation, there's a lot that's changed there.

Now we've been an innovation, technology-driven company in our payments group for 2 decades. Our Elavon group has had agile studios going back to 2000 before anyone even knew what an agile studio was. But the fact was it was a little bit isolated in that group. In the last 18 months, it's been expanded to across the bank. We currently have 22 agile studios impacting every business line, it has completely changed the way we develop and execute in terms of our product management and product development. It's faster, it's quicker to market, it's much more customer centric and it's much more efficient, and you're going to hear more about that. But it's a new way of doing business. And that 22, I would expect to expand to double in the next year. That has allowed us to introduce some of the things you see on that slide like increased automated underwriting, instant decisioning. You're going to hear about some of the products and on revamped mobile app.

And finally, we've had a number of changes in the executive leadership. Probably the most recent -- certainly the most recent change is the creation of a Chief Digital Officer position. You're going to hear from Derek White later this morning. But I believe so strongly that the digital component of our success is critical that we created a managing level committee position that looks across the company at all the digital initiatives and making sure we're having this in a consistent, effective way introduced to all the clients regardless of business line and Derek's going to give you the vision around that shortly.

We have new leaders across HR and risk. Tim has taken over the combined Consumer and Business Banking group. And Gunjan is here today. At the last earnings call, I think Gunjan you were on the phone, you were 1 month away from starting, you wanted to make sure we had a good earnings call before we started but she is now here to talk about wealth management. So a lot's changed in the industry. A lot's changed at the bank, and I want to tell you well, how I think about where we are today.

Three things. Number one, I believe we're starting from a great position of strength. I will tell you this very honestly, I wouldn't trade places with anyone else in our peer group, and I'm going to tell you why. But I think we have all the attributes and the exact right timing to be really successful in this new environment.

Number two, those core competencies and advantages that got us here, that got us to this point to that position of strength that I talked about continue, and we're focused on retaining those strengths.

And number three, we recognize that the future is changing, and we have to continue to adjust to be successful in that new future.

Now let me talk about the position that we're (inaudible). So you all know that we're the fifth largest bank in the country. Just over $480 billion in assets and just over $80 billion of market cap. This is a great position to be in. Why is that? Because we're able to spend $2.5 billion in technology and operations around innovation on an annual basis. And that's important because that is much more than the banks below us are spending, number one. And number two is while the banks above us are spending more than that, we have a much simpler, less complex more straightforward business model.

So I would maintain that our $2.5 billion is much more effectively spent in terms of outcomes and production, and we're able to do that in this environment in a -- moving a lot more of our projects from defense to offense. You're going to hear a lot about that in a moment, but we're making tremendous progress. So when you think about M&A, coming back to that point about the industry, M&A is occurring in the industry and in payments for 2 reasons: number one is scale and number two is capabilities.

We believe we have the scale as I've already talked about, and importantly, we already have this great payments business sitting in U.S. Bank. And our objective is to weave that into the banking component because of the importance of payments and banking coming together in this new environment.

So really we have the scale and the competencies to be successful. So we do not believe we need to do an acquisition. However, it would not be prudent of us to put our head in the sand and not be aware what's going on in the market. So we will look at opportunities as they present themselves under the following lens, it's a long-term lens. You're going to hear about a lot of progress today, and we've made a lot of progress across the company and the momentum is terrific. So as we think about deals, we recognize that there's going to be a distraction with the deal, somewhere in the neighborhood of 18 months to 2.5 years. So the question we ask is will we be a better bank after that's done, 3 to 4 years from now than we would be on our own with the momentum we're making. So we're not looking at the short term or the day 1 announcement or that initial financial projection. It's the long-term positioning of the company and making sure we're in the best position possible given the momentum we have and that's how we think about it.

Now the second thing you'll notice from this chart is we are more valuable than we are big. If you look at the left-hand side, you'll see 1/4 of the size of the bank above us in terms of asset size. But if you look at the right, we're more than 1/2 in terms of value. And one of the key reasons for that is our returns. From an ROE, ROA and efficiency standpoint, this chart is the last 3 years. We are #1, #1 and #1. But if I did the last 10 years, we have the same position, #1 across the board. It's function of a lot of things but I wanted -- the message to you is our intent to retain that position in this new environment regardless of what happens.

And if you step back and look at our advantages, I'm going to classify them in 4 categories. I already talked about our financial discipline and our financial measurements. I would also maintain -- so we have a very good offense. I would also maintain, we have the best defense. You're going to hear from both Terry and Mark in terms of when the rough -- when the road gets rougher, we actually perform even better. That's true in the CCAR process, we have the least amount of capital implication. We make money even out of the most severely adverse scenario. It's true of our charge-off volatility, which is much less volatile in a harsh environment than anyone else. And importantly, we haven't changed our stripes in our credit underwriting so that financial discipline, that risk discipline which leads to the highest debt ratings in our peer group and among the highest on the globe, which is a tremendous advantage from a funding cost standpoint, a competence standpoint and a counterparty of choice standpoint. Huge opportunity, huge advantage and one that's very important to us.

Secondly, our business mix. We have this great diversity of businesses that offer diversity of sources of income about 1/2 of it, a little less than half in fees. Some of it from net interest income and together they really diversify during economic cycles. And importantly, unlike a number of banks, we have a number of unique business lines. Corporate trust, fund services and payments that are very capital efficient, high return, scalable businesses that we have a huge advantage in, which drives the efficiencies and the returns that I just talked about.

Number three, I talk about trust, confidence, being so important in this environment, and Kate will share with you some of the facts about how we've positioned -- how we're positioned very well from a trust standpoint.

We've always done things for the right reasons. Our employees are highly engaged. And that trust factor, which I think is even more important in this environment, is one that we're starting from a position of strength. And finally, our strategy, which is 4 simple components: number one, retaining the financial and risk management discipline, our trusted choice component; number two is looking at activities across the bank just like that across the bank. We spend very little time as a team thinking about business line by business line and really thinking about the customer at the center of everything we do; number three on the right, I'm a big believer in this, I think we have a great opportunity to continue to drive for simplicity across the company. Simplicity in the way customers deal with us and make it simple for employees to do their job.

And then finally, the future. We understand that things are changing rapidly. We're not going to just sit back and say, we've got it all in place. We don't need to change it all because we know what we're doing, and we'll just keep doing what we're doing. We need to adjust and we're recognizing that. So for those of you in the audience who have invested with us for the last 10 years, the good news is, those things that you invested in us for, our financial discipline, our business mix, our risk management and our culture are not going to change.

Those strengths are strengths that we recognize are critically important for the future, and we're not going to change our stripes.

However, I believe and our team believes strongly that those are necessary but insufficient to be successful in the future under this new environment. And the pivot we need to make while retaining those core competencies is to be more agile, innovative and you're going to hear this theme throughout the day more digitally focused across the board. So as we think about what we're investing in the future, I want to talk about this sort of balance.

One of you in the room came to speak to our Board about 2 years ago. And you said one of the things we like about U.S. Bank is that they manage the company forever, and that was a great way to say it because that's exactly how we think about it. We're managing a company for the long term. However, we recognize that while we manage the company for the long term, we need to perform in the short term.

I get that too, so I will never forget that. So this is great balance that we're looking at, which is optimizing things we're doing today to continue to invest for the things we want to be great at tomorrow.

The optimization on the left-hand side includes things like our business mix. So we've actually exited a number of businesses that either have limited competitive advantage from our perspective, are not going to be as critical in the future because they're paper-based businesses or demand a lot of investment with limited return.

Businesses like Retail Lockbox and our ATM driving business with cash operations, and we're going to continue to look at optimizing our business mix. I talked about physical asset optimization, a great opportunity for both efficiencies and effectiveness of what's going on in a branch, and we're looking at that across the board. Upper right, structure. Terry will talk about this a little bit more. We're looking across the company for spans of control and the way we're managing call centers across every area of the company looking for optimization and efficiencies.

And you're going to hear from Jeff on technology and risk. But technology and risk is an investment for the future but also optimizing the current, and Jeff's going to talk a lot about that. So we're doing all those things to optimize what we have here now in order to be successful in investing in the digital money movement capabilities as well as new markets in the future.

And as we think about that future investment, I think about it across 3 horizons. On a core business model, we want to be the very best consumer in business bank, the very best wealth manager, the very best payments business and corporate and commercial bank in the industry and running that as effectively for the benefit of our customers as possible. While at the same time, transforming the way we're doing that business, seeking that optimization and recognizing the technical investments that we need to make to continue going forward. And that middle category is sort of this horizon of 1 to 3 years. And all the while, looking at that future that horizon that's a little longer, little less clear but we know there are certain components that we need to have core capabilities to drive our success and have that agility and digital focus. So across those 3 horizons, we're focused on these 5 things.

Number one, relentlessly focusing on the customer. Everything we do at the company is with the customer in the center and all of our capabilities around that. The way we think about product development, technology, service, operations, communications, we're looking at the customer at the core of what we do.

Secondly, and you're -- if you do a word count, and what you're going to hear the word most today is going to be digital. I believe that digital is critical to the future of our success and being able to deliver digital capabilities in a seamless, convenient, agile, quick fashion is going to be critically important and we're investing heavily in that.

Data. Banks have always been great collectors of data, and have always been lousy users of data, right? And what we're focused on is collecting that data and using it for the benefit of the customers. You're going to hear about insights, insights to consumers around their objectives of savings goals and financial goals overall. Insights to businesses, to help them improve the way they're running their business. And that data component combined with that digital component is critically important.

Partnerships is another one. The other thing that we recognize is that we can't build everything ourselves and be everything to all customers. And you're going to hear about some of the partnerships today with some fintech players where they have as core capability, typically in a thin, unregulated slice of a capability often a front-end combined with our balance sheet, our customer base, our underwriting and our risk discipline. Together, we are stronger than we are separately, and we're going to continue to focus on partnerships across the board.

And then finally, really this concept of one U.S. Bank, breaking down the barriers of businesses, thinking about the customers and not just the way we're dealing with customers but internally the way we're optimizing across the company. We no longer do our investment prioritization business line by business line, we do it as a company. We do it as one entity across the board. So that's our focus area.

Now I know a lot of you have followed the company for a long time, and we have always focused on those things that we can control, and we will continue to do that. I can't control the economic environment, the interest rate environment but I can control the expenses and the optimization that we focused on. We're past our build on compliance as I talked about into the optimization phase. We've increased the tax relief in 2017, allowed us to increase our investment spend, which is now on the run rate and that's part of that $2.5 billion a year that I've talked about, and then we're looking for optimization across the board.

Terry is going to talk about our capital investment, and you're going to hear a lot about our investment overall -- capital return and our investment overall. Now one of the things I also recognize back to that balance component is we need to continue to perform in the short term and we're looking at the long term. And there were a few years principally during the consent order process that we were not able to deliver positive operating leverage. And I know that's important to you, it's important to me and our management team. However, in 7 of the past 8 quarters, we did deliver positive operating leverage for all the reasons I talked about. And on the second quarter call, and we've talked about it a few times, our objective was to achieve it in the range of 100 to 150 basis points for the year. Now since then as you know, rates have come down and the rate scenario has changed dramatically. And so while our intent is to continue to achieve positive operating leverage and to continue to have low single-digit expense growth, it's likely that we'll be somewhat below that 1% positive operating leverage in 2019 but still delivering positive operating leverage. Because if we did the things that would need -- or caused us to get to that level, it would not be prudent for the long term, and we want to manage this company for the long term and that's how we're thinking about it.

So as we think about how all this adds up, and I'm going to shortcut a slide that Terry is going to give you because it's so important is whatever the environment is, whatever the interest rate, the credit environment is in the long term, it's our intent to continue to return 14.5% to 17.5% ROE to our shareholders. We believe we have the business mix, the disciplines, the strengths, the core capabilities to do that on a consistent basis over the long term and that is our intent and Terry will talk more about the details about that in a moment. And that translates into a tangible return on equity somewhere between 18% and 20%. So I believe we're in a great spot. I believe we have the great -- the core capabilities, the strengths that have gotten us there and we're going to continue to maintain them, but we're going to build from that success given the future and what's important in the long term in order to be successful over the next 3, 5 and 10 years and that's the way we think about the company.

So what are you going to hear about today? We're going to split the discussion a little bit in terms of broad initiatives across the company, business line updates and then talking about our risk and financial discipline at the end. So at the beginning here, you're going to hear Kate talk about brand and culture and how important that is to our success and our unique position in that regard. You're going to hear Jeff von Gillern talk about our technology group, and he's going to talk about it both from the perspective of offense as well as defense and he's -- we have a great position on that on both sides. And then we're going to wrap up the morning part of this -- the first part of the morning with Derek talking about our digital strategy.

So again, thank you for your time and attention. I'm really excited about the story we're going to tell you, and we're going to kick it off with Kate Quinn, our Chief Administrative Officer, who's been with the company 6 years. Kate?

KATHERINE B. QUINN, VICE CHAIRMAN & CHIEF ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER, U.S. BANCORP: Good morning. Brand and culture are differentiators for U.S. Bank and they are fundamental to how we run our business. When we met last year in 2016, we talked about how strong brands drive better shareholder return. They also drive higher top line growth and they outperform the S&P 500. I'll tell you today what we've done on our brand journey since then, where we're positioned and what's next for us.

So increasingly, people are not just buying what you do, they're buying why you do it. So when we began our brand journey, we started from the inside out. We started with our culture, which is a unique combination of IQ and EQ and that is reflected in our purpose statement. We invest our hearts and minds to power human potential. The trend of culture is very important. So when you think about the sea of black and white banking, this gray space is really, really important, the space of brand and culture. It unifies and rallies employees and it's why is felt across all of our stakeholders.

The intersection of brand and culture is differentiating, and it is really the unwritten rule set in which all decisions are made inside the company, and where -- is felt to all of our stakeholders again and it's how we conduct business. We were at a leadership off-site this past summer and we asked our top 200 leaders what is the secret sauce of U.S. Bank, and this is the word cloud that emerged from that. So for those of us who live and breathe it every day, it's no surprise that ethics, trust and collaboration rose to the top.

As I mentioned why it's felt across all of our stakeholder groups. For employees, it is -- our purpose is motivating for them, and we hear it all the time and there's a reason why we attract and retain top talent across the company. For our customers, they feel it in all of our efforts to earn their trust. And in fact, when we test proof points, when we test products and services, we test marketing messages, we test everything. Ethics and trust rises to the #1 spot for all customer segments, both consumers and businesses.

In terms of communities, we have an industry-leading reputation with our community partners, and again, it isn't because necessarily of what we do but how and why we engage with them. And lastly, you all feel it as well and our other shareholders. It's felt in our best-in-class return, our focus on the long term and our consistent performance of course. But we often know that expectations are definitely changing. So all stakeholders are now really expecting brands to have a voice on social issues. In fact, 92% of millennials want to work for and believe it's important to work for a company that has a social conscience. We hear it from all of our stakeholders internally and externally.

We also know that this heightened set of expectations is not just important to our customers and employees but it's also important to you. We hear the questions from you as well. So when we think about our social responsibility strategy and our focus, we've always been good at it, but we're getting even stronger at it, and we're focused in 3 areas: first, making sure that what we do has social impact and there are -- examples of this are things like enabling access to capital, financial wellness programs; secondly, we're focused on diversity, equity and inclusion, this is a critical focus area for us; and lastly, making sure that we're doing our part to address environmental challenges, and we do that through our products and services, through our partnerships but also through accountability and governance around these issues. So we will make sure to keep you posted as we evolve this strategy.

So you can probably tell when we started our brand launch, we were not focused on advertising. We were really focused on telling -- capturing and telling our story in a better, more integrated and consistent way across all of our stakeholder groups internally and externally, digitally and socially. And we also -- as Andy mentioned, we've really changed our focus from thinking about ourselves and presenting ourselves as a regional brand to presenting ourselves as a national brand. And of course, being a bank, we measure everything we do. And so we know that we have had strong impact. As expected, our brand awareness in U.S. Bank has increased over these past few years. We've also strengthened our most trusted choice positioning. We've had an undeniable positive impact on revenue and deposit share.

And lastly, we've also increased our, what we call, central customers, which are customers that have a deeper relationship with the bank. They're more engaged and more involved with us and you'll hear about [centralities] throughout the deck. So brand finance recognizes that we've increased our brand by 55% over the past 3 years and lots of other brands also recognized our performance from an external perspective. So for example, Ethisphere, Fortune, Forbes, DiversityInc.

In terms of our reputation with community partners, I mentioned this before, we have the strongest reputation amongst all banks with community partners. And again, this is because of how we engage with them, and how we commit to our success and their success within our communities. In terms of employee engagement, we historically have industry and company leading employee engagement scores. And we know that companies with highly engaged workforces outperform their peers by nearly 150%. Focusing on culture is good business. And when we think about how do we translate that employee engagement and our brand to growth, it's a very simple equation. Higher employee engagement leads to a stronger customer experience, which leads to revenue, retention and growth. So when we think about our employees and our customers, we think about them in a very similar way. This is all leveraged with data, analytics and insights that help us focus on knowing exactly what you spend time on.

So we work on attracting, retaining and developing our relationships with both employees and customers. And we focus on 3 things: one, creating compelling journeys for them both. For example, personalizing their experiences with us; secondly, enhancing and enabling their digital lives. As Andy said, you'll hear the word digital throughout the day; and lastly, by establishing really deep and meaningful relationships with both. This helps us build our customer brand as well as our employee brand resulting again in revenue, retention and growth. Trust will remain a competitive advantage for us. It is not going anywhere. It is going to be a foundational driver, top driver of business in our industry. As the world evolves, we will remain competitive, we will stay relevant with our brand, and we'll focus on the moments that matter to our employees and our customers.

We will continue to drive impact through our social strategies, and we will build trust at moments that matter most. We will tell our story through our brand campaign but really, our employees are our best brand ambassadors.

Let me just give you one example of that. In Northern California, during the wildfires, many employees and customers lost their homes. We weren't able to open our branch. We have a Branch Manager named [Taylor], and Taylor opened up his home to employees that had lost their homes. He invited them to stay with him, live with him. And from his home, he reached out to customers to make sure that they were safe, that they had what they needed during the crisis. This is a great example of our unique culture and how that impacts our customers in a positive way. Brands have become an agent of change at the bank. It supported some of our most critical initiatives and it grows engagement as well as revenue. It is a core competency for us and it is foundational to how we conduct our business every day. It's also foundational to the story that you will hear for the rest of the day. Brand and culture will remain differentiators for us to our business growth and success. Thank you.

ANDREW CECERE: Thanks, Kate. And [Taylor] is one of my heroes. I called him after that fire. And he said, "You know what we're going to do, Andy? We're going to roast marshmallows." He was just -- he just had the best attitude I've ever seen. So just a great example of the employee base that we have.

So we're going to go from sort of the soft gray as you talked about, Kate, but important components to 0 and 1.
